children.subject:
Have not taken 162 so I will just comment. If memory management is your weak point, you're in luck because 61C has a ton of resources for you to review it. I'll just list the few I remember off the top of my head.

1) K&R book. Read chapters on memory, malloc, calloc, and realloc to understand the syntax

2) Hilfinger's note on memory management http://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~cs61c/resources/pnh.stg.mgmt.pdf

3) Section 6 of Harvey's C note: http://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~cs61c/resources/HarveyNotesC1-3.pdf

4) C pointers and arrays lecture: http://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~cs61c/fa17/lec/03/L03%20C%20and%20Pointers%20(1up).pdf

5) Memory management lecture: http://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~cs61c/fa17/lec/04/L04%20Mem%20MGMT%20(1up).pdf

I personally found memory management topics much easier to digest after understanding how arrays and pointers are represented in memory. Having a visual understanding (essentially box and pointer diagrams) is critical to learning memory management in my opinion.

Good luck!

history.content: I don't recommend taking 162 without a solid grasp of memory representation and allocation, but that doesn't mean you need to drop the class. Spend this weekend reviewing that topic from the links provided below and anything you can find online. Maybe make it into a small personal project you can show recruiters.
I find C language is tricky if it relates to memory allocation. I am not sure if I should drop 162 at this point. Any suggestion?
history.subject: How likely am I to pass 162(operating system) with 61C not passed?
